title: 105_hr4539
content: The "Consular Review Act of 1998" establishes a Board of Visa Appeals under the Immigration and Nationality Act. The Secretary of State shall establish a Board of Visa Appeals composed of 5 members, with no more than 2 being consular officers. The Board has authority to review discretionary decisions of consular officers regarding immigrant and nonimmigrant visas, petitions, and waiver applications under section 212. The Board of Visa Appeals can review decisions made by consular officers on visas, petitions, and waiver applications. The Board can overrule or remand decisions if they are contrary to the evidence presented. Proceedings before the Board must follow regulations set by the Secretary of State. The interested party shall be notified of the review process and steps to request it. A written record of the proceedings and decision shall be available to the Board and the alien upon request. The Board must notify the consular officer within 30 days of a review request. The appellant will receive notice as well. The Board reviews decisions upon request from the alien or interested parties. The appellant must be given notice of the proceedings and can choose their own counsel. Requests for review must be made in writing within 60 days of denial, revocation, or cancellation. Interested parties include the petitioner or beneficiary of an approved immigrant visa petition. Interested parties eligible for review by the Board include the petitioner or beneficiary of approved immigrant visa petitions, petitioner of nonimmigrant visa petitions, postsecondary educational institutions for nonimmigrant students, recognized international agencies, and treaty investors or traders in the United States. The Board allows for review requests from various eligible parties, including petitioners of immigrant and nonimmigrant visa petitions, educational institutions, international agencies, and treaty investors or traders in the United States. The review process has limitations on frequency and fees, with the amendment taking effect 120 days after the enactment of the Act. The amendment made by subsection (a) will take effect 120 days after the enactment of the Act. Proposed regulations must be issued within 30 days, and members of the Board of Visa Appeals must be appointed within 120 days. Technical amendments are made to section 222(f) of the Immigration and Nationality Act. The amendment includes changes to sections 104(a)(1) and the table of contents of the Act. It allows interested parties to inspect the record of proceedings. The amendment includes the creation of the Board of Visa Appeals under Section 225 of the Act.
